statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Anthony Barber scored 16 points, and North Carolina State beat No. 15 North Carolina 58-46 on Tuesday night, earning its first road win in the series in a dozen years.
article.shortLinkText: NC State tops UNC for rare road win

related.description: North Carolina State sophomore point guard Anthony "Cat" Barber has developed just in time, C.L. Brown writes.
related.linkText: Brown: Focused Anthony Barber keeping Wolfpack a cut above
related.title: Brown: Focused Anthony Barber keeping Wolfpack a cut above
related.headline: Brown: Focused Anthony Barber keeping Wolfpack a cut above

article.headline: NC State upends No. 15 UNC for first win in Chapel Hill in 12 years
article.linkText: NC State tops UNC for rare road win
article.story:
CHAPEL HILL, N.C. -- North Carolina State arrived at North Carolina focused more on getting another road win to help its NCAA tournament chances than trying to end its long drought at the Smith Center.

The Wolfpack ended up taking care of both in impressive fashion.

Anthony Barber scored 15 points, and NC State beat the 15th-ranked Tar Heels 58-46 on Tuesday night, earning its first road win in the series in a dozen years.

Trevor Lacey and Ralston Turner each added 14 points for the Wolfpack (17-11, 8-7 Atlantic Coast Conference), who earned a second marquee road victory this month in pursuit of a fourth straight NCAA trip.

"Our focus was just to come in and win," Lacey said. "It wasn't make history or none of that."

NC State didn't shoot particularly well, but it played with toughness and composure while frustrating the Tar Heels (19-9, 9-6) just about all night.

By the end, NC State had held UNC to its lowest point total in its nearly three-decade run in the Smith Center. Not to mention beat a Roy Williams-coached Tar Heels team in Chapel Hill for the first time ever.

"I think our guys came in here with a great belief and great confidence in themselves," NC State coach Mark Gottfried said.

UNC had won 17 of 18 meetings overall and hadn't lost to NC State in Chapel Hill since 2003, the season before Williams left Kansas to take over at his alma mater.

NC State has been living on the NCAA tournament bubble for a solid month. It followed an upset of then-unbeaten Duke with six losses in eight games and looked sunk, only to follow that with a road upset against top-10 Louisville on Feb. 14 and now another big one.

"It would be easy to think this has made our season and drop the rest," Turner said. "We just have to be mature about the situation."

NC State led by 11 at halftime, then as many as 16 early in the second half. Then, after the Tar Heels ran off 12 straight points to build momentum and erase nearly all the deficit, the Wolfpack hung in and kept just enough control to hang on.

"We did some good things at times," Williams said, "but the bottom line is North Carolina State kicked our rear ends."

Freshman Justin Jackson scored 16 points for the Tar Heels, who shot 35 percent.

TIP-INS

NC State: NC State shot just 35 percent for the game. ... The Wolfpack finished with a 41-38 rebounding advantage. ... The Wolfpack went 8-for-11 at the line after halftime. ... Beejay Anya had six blocks to lead a strong defensive effort up front.

UNC: Kennedy Meeks finished with 12 points and 14 rebounds. ... UNC shot 3-for-12 from 3-point range. ... The Tar Heels shot just 7-for-25 (28 percent) in the first half. ... Williams had been critical of a home crowd that was "asleep" during Saturday's rout of Georgia Tech. He said this one was "sensational" only to have his team "let them down." ... Williams fell to 23-3 against NC State as UNC's coach.

TURNER'S BIG NIGHT

Turner scored 11 after halftime. That included two 3s at absolutely huge times, one after UNC had closed the gap to 38-36 and the second with NC State up 45-41 with about 5 1/2 minutes left.

NO-SHOWS

UNC's starting five largely sputtered offensively.

Preseason All-American Marcus Paige had seven points on 3-for-8 shooting. Forward Brice Johnson -- who had been averaging 17.4 points per game and shooting 63 percent over the previous five games -- finished with four points on 1-for-6 shooting.

And J.P. Tokoto, who had appeared to break loose from a recent funk last week, scored three on 1-for-6 shooting.

"We got the shots we wanted," Paige said. "We didn't make very many of them obviously. Sometimes the ball just doesn't go in."

UP NEXT

NC State travels to Boston College on Saturday.

UNC travels to Miami on Saturday.
